dialogueTree.title: Mainframe: "Tiles on the cube are still smoulde..."
dialogueTree.text: Tiles on the cube are still smouldering, casting the framework in a soft glow. Virescent PLAY and PRINT keys shine on the keyboard.

links.title: You: "Look inside the compartment."
links.text: Look inside the compartment.

links.title: Mainframe: "Behind the hatch sits a cube-like c..."
links.text: Behind the hatch sits a cube-like crisscross of filaments, smouldering in the dark like fireflies. Silver tape on the side says in a black marker: "THE PRODUCTION SCHEDULE".

links.title: Mainframe: "Behind the hatch sits a cube-like c..."
links.text: Behind the hatch sits a cube-like crisscross of filaments, smouldering in the dark like fireflies. Silver tape on the side says in a black marker: "THE OFF-SITE COPY".

links.title: Mainframe: "It's empty like a beehive without i..."
links.text: It's empty like a beehive without its brood. Some cables have been left dangling, disconnected...

links.title: Interfacing: "The filaments you have would fit pe..."
links.text: The filaments you have would fit perfectly inside the compartment.

links.title: Interfacing: "The filament you have would fit per..."
links.text: The filament you have would fit perfectly inside the compartment.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""This is where the memory should go..."
links.text: "This is where the memory should go," the lieutenant notes, observing the machine.

links.title: Interfacing: "This is where the machine's memory..."
links.text: This is where the machine's memory should go.

links.title: You: "Insert THE OFF-SITE COPY."
links.text: Insert THE OFF-SITE COPY.

links.title: Mainframe: "Like a smooth drawer, the filament..."
links.text: Like a smooth drawer, the filament slides into place. On the keyboard, the PLAY key starts blinking.

links.title: You: "Insert THE PRODUCTION SCHEDULE."
links.text: Insert THE PRODUCTION SCHEDULE.

links.title: Mainframe: "Like a smooth drawer, the filament..."
links.text: Like a smooth drawer, the filament slides into place. On the keyboard, the PLAY key starts blinking.

links.title: You: "Remove THE OFF-SITE COPY."
links.text: Remove THE OFF-SITE COPY.

links.title: Mainframe: "The filament slides out of its glow..."
links.text: The filament slides out of its glowing nest.

links.title: You: "Remove THE PRODUCTION SCHEDULE."
links.text: Remove THE PRODUCTION SCHEDULE.

links.title: You: "Press PLAY."
links.text: Press PLAY.

links.title: Mainframe: "The speaker comes to life, static s..."
links.text: The speaker comes to life, static seeps through the machine's planar magnetic driver. An old lady greets you, her voice sounds a hundred years old...

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Good morning, Fortress Accident on..."
links.text: "Good morning, Fortress Accident on Rue de Saint-Ghislaine, this is East-Insulindian Repeater Station 1."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Please repeat -- is this the produ..."
links.text: "Please repeat -- is this the production schedule?"

links.title: You: ""Yvonne, it's me again! How are you?""
links.text: "Yvonne, it's me again! How are you?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Good, thank you." It's not clear w..."
links.text: "Good, thank you." It's not clear whether she recognizes your voice. "Please repeat, how can I help you?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Good, thank you." It's not clear w..."
links.text: "Good, thank you." It's not clear whether she recognizes your voice. "Please repeat, is this the production schedule?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Good, thank you." It's not clear w..."
links.text: "Good, thank you." It's not clear whether she recognizes your voice. "Please repeat, is this the off-site copy?"

links.title: You: ""Let's try the password for the pro..."
links.text: "Let's try the password for the production schedule."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Good. Please repeat the password.""
links.text: "Good. Please repeat the password."

links.title: You: "Say: "After death -- life again.""
links.text: Say: "After death -- life again."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Good, I've unlocked the off-site c..."
links.text: "Good, I've unlocked the off-site copy. After ending the call, please press PRINT to access the filament."

links.title: Conceptualization: "*Ka-ching*!"
links.text: *Ka-ching*!

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Fortress Accident, is there anythi..."
links.text: "Fortress Accident, is there anything else I can do for you today?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""No, that's not it.""
links.text: "No, that's not it."

links.title: Half Light: "Unbelievable!!! Who came up with th..."
links.text: Unbelievable!!! Who came up with those stupid passwords!

links.title: You: "Say: "After life -- death.""
links.text: Say: "After life -- death."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Good, I've unlocked the production..."
links.text: "Good, I've unlocked the production schedule. After ending the call, please press PRINT to access the filament."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Really? She just used the same pas..."
links.text: "Really? She just used the same password?" The lieutenant seems almost disappointed to discover that, as he murmurs:  "Maybe those radiocomputer guys aren't that paranoid after all..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Really? She just used the same pas..."
links.text: "Really? She just used the same password?" The lieutenant seems almost disappointed to discover that.

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: "Her answer is short and sharp: "No,..."
links.text: Her answer is short and sharp: "No, that's not it."

links.title: Half Light: "What does she mean *that's not it*?..."
links.text: What does she mean *that's not it*?! What's the password then???

links.title: Conceptualization: "Maybe it's the second part of the l..."
links.text: Maybe it's the second part of the leitmotiv you saw on the stained glass window.

links.title: You: ""A password? I'm really bad at pass..."
links.text: "A password? I'm really bad at passwords. Can you give me a hint?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Still no.""
links.text: "Still no."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""No.""
links.text: "No."

links.title: Encyclopedia: "A hint system is not part of the pr..."
links.text: A hint system is not part of the protocol for repeater stations.

links.title: You: ""Is it my birthday?""
links.text: "Is it my birthday?"

links.title: You: ""This is the police. Please open th..."
links.text: "This is the police. Please open this thing."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: "The voice recites: "I am contractua..."
links.text: The voice recites: "I am contractually obliged to protect the privacy of the filament holder Fortress Accident. Without filing a warrant with Lintel, I cannot give you access to this filament."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""I'm afraid we're not doing that. U..."
links.text: "I'm afraid we're not doing that. Unless we want to wait for a month."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Now, can you please repeat the pas..."
links.text: "Now, can you please repeat the password?" the voice in the machine asks again. She sounds cold in the damp air.

links.title: You: ""I don't know the password.""
links.text: "I don't know the password."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Received. I will *register* this l..."
links.text: "Received. I will *register* this log-in attempt."

links.title: Logic: "Don't worry. Passwords have a way o..."
links.text: Don't worry. Passwords have a way of *turning up* sooner or later.

links.title: Reaction Speed: "Don't worry. Passwords have a way o..."
links.text: Don't worry. Passwords have a way of *turning up* sooner or later.

links.title: Half Light: "That sounds bad -- a log-in *attemp..."
links.text: That sounds bad -- a log-in *attempt*. Something a criminal would do.

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Received. I will *register* this l..."
links.text: "Received. I will *register* this log-in attempt."

links.title: Logic: "Password. Of course it would have a..."
links.text: Password. Of course it would have a password. That's why there's a human administrator involved.

links.title: Suggestion: "You should ask her for a hint."
links.text: You should ask her for a hint.

links.title: You: ""I might have a password for the of..."
links.text: "I might have a password for the off-site copy."

links.title: You: ""What's the production schedule?""
links.text: "What's the production schedule?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""The filament you have inserted int..."
links.text: "The filament you have inserted into the reader."

links.title: You: ""You mean that glowing thing I put..."
links.text: "You mean that glowing thing I put inside?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Yes. Is that the production schedu..."
links.text: "Yes. Is that the production schedule?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Yes. Is that the off-site copy?""
links.text: "Yes. Is that the off-site copy?"

links.title: You: ""Ah, right. Thanks for the explanat..."
links.text: "Ah, right. Thanks for the explanation."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""That was a question. Have you inse..."
links.text: "That was a question. Have you inserted it into the core?"

links.title: You: ""Yes.""
links.text: "Yes."

links.title: You: ""I don't know.""
links.text: "I don't know."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: "The old lady sighs, as a wave of st..."
links.text: The old lady sighs, as a wave of static distorts her voice to a robotic sprawl. "If you are unsure, could you please take a look?"

links.title: You: ""How do I do that?""
links.text: "How do I do that?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Open the hatch on the compartment...."
links.text: "Open the hatch on the compartment. Don't touch the wires, a current is running through it, but the core is safe. There's a filament inside -- I need to know what it's called."

links.title: You: ""It's called the production schedul..."
links.text: "It's called the production schedule."

links.title: You: ""It's called the off-site copy.""
links.text: "It's called the off-site copy."

links.title: You: ""I swear I haven't touched anything!""
links.text: "I swear I haven't touched anything!"

links.title: You: ""What's the off-site copy?""
links.text: "What's the off-site copy?"

links.title: You: ""Why did you call me Fortress Accid..."
links.text: "Why did you call me Fortress Accident?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Fortress Accident is the company o..."
links.text: "Fortress Accident is the company on whose name the terminal you're currently using has been registered to."

links.title: You: ""Do you have any other information..."
links.text: "Do you have any other information about this company?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""One moment..." You hear her flip t..."
links.text: "One moment..." You hear her flip through a catalogue, before she reads out with studious care:

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""'Fortress Accident SCA produces re..."
links.text: "'Fortress Accident SCA produces revolutionary interactive call-in radio games' -- that's what the catalogue says."

links.title: Conceptualization: "That's not bad."
links.text: That's not bad.

links.title: You: ""Wow. So conceptual.""
links.text: "Wow. So conceptual."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Hmm," she hums."
links.text: "Hmm," she hums.

links.title: You: ""And what's that -- this 'interacti..."
links.text: "And what's that -- this 'interactive call-in radio game'?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: "The static drowns her response. "An..."
links.text: The static drowns her response. "Any other questions?" you hear her ask when the connection finally improves.

links.title: You: ""What are you, a *machine*? Or are..."
links.text: "What are you, a *machine*? Or are you *alive*?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Yes, I am alive. I am 74 years old..."
links.text: "Yes, I am alive. I am 74 years old and my name is Yvonne."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant whispers into your e..."
links.text: The lieutenant whispers into your ear: "She repeats passwords. Programming people are all... paranoid."

links.title: You: ""Yvonne, my partner tells me that y..."
links.text: "Yvonne, my partner tells me that you're here because radiocomputer guys are all paranoid."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""They're merely cautious," says the..."
links.text: "They're merely cautious," says the old lady. "It's my job to protect their filaments as a password repeater at the East-Insulindian Station."

links.title: You: ""Okay, but where are you? How did y..."
links.text: "Okay, but where are you? How did you know where I am?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""I work as a repeater at the East-I..."
links.text: "I work as a repeater at the East-Insulindian Repeater Station. It's my job to know where you are, Fortress Accident."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""As for me, well..." Some static. T..."
links.text: "As for me, well..." Some static. Then... "I am sitting in my cubicle surrounded by a wall of radios."

links.title: Shivers: "On an island on the River Esperance..."
links.text: On an island on the River Esperance, a small woman, all skin and bones, sits in a room filled with audio equipment. Thousands of tiny lights are reflected back from her prescription lenses, like stars in the dark.

links.title: Empathy: "Doesn't it get lonely, sitting ther..."
links.text: Doesn't it get lonely, sitting there all by herself?

links.title: You: ""Doesn't it get lonely, doing this..."
links.text: "Doesn't it get lonely, doing this job?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Lonely?" For the first time you he..."
links.text: "Lonely?" For the first time you hear her chuckle through the rustle of static. "Why would it get lonely, I get to talk to people all day."

links.title: Empathy: "That's why she does this."
links.text: That's why she does this.

links.title: You: "Let it go."
links.text: Let it go.

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Now please tell me if there's anyt..."
links.text: "Now please tell me if there's anything else I can do, Fortress Accident."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Now please tell me the reason for..."
links.text: "Now please tell me the reason for your call, Fortress Accident."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Yes, I am alive. I am 74 years old..."
links.text: "Yes, I am alive. I am 74 years old and my name is Yvonne. Now please repeat, is this the production schedule?"

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Yes, I am alive. I am 74 years old..."
links.text: "Yes, I am alive. I am 74 years old and my name is Yvonne. Now please repeat, is this the off-site copy?"

links.title: You: ""That's all for now." (Press OFF/SI..."
links.text: "That's all for now." (Press OFF/SILENT.)

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Thank you and good bye," the old l..."
links.text: "Thank you and good bye," the old lady's voice disappears along with the static.

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Please repeat, is this the off-sit..."
links.text: "Please repeat, is this the off-site copy?"

links.title: Interfacing: "This is a *human interface* -- a re..."
links.text: This is a *human interface* -- a retired person sitting behind a switchboard somewhere.

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Good afternoon, Fortress Accident..."
links.text: "Good afternoon, Fortress Accident on Rue de Saint-Ghislaine, this is East-Insulindian Repeater Station 1."

links.title: East-Insulindian Repeater Station: ""Good evening, Fortress Accident on..."
links.text: "Good evening, Fortress Accident on Rue de Saint-Ghislaine, this is East-Insulindian Repeater Station 1."

links.title: Mainframe: "A bar of fabric right above the key..."
links.text: A bar of fabric right above the keyboard starts producing a soft hum. The sound of static seeps through the machine's planar magnetic driver.

links.title: Inland Empire: "Have you stirred the ghost of the D..."
links.text: Have you stirred the ghost of the Doomed Commercial Area from its rest? Could this be its dismembered heart, beginning to flutter?

links.title: Half Light: "Oh no... it was already glowing and..."
links.text: Oh no... it was already glowing and now it's also making a *sound*? It's probably some alien Seolite technology...

links.title: Mainframe: "The static gets louder, slowly fill..."
links.text: The static gets louder, slowly filling up the abandoned hall. Until a voice speaks out, crackling and old, cutting into the air...

links.title: Mainframe: "Nothing happens."
links.text: Nothing happens.

links.title: Interfacing: "Something's missing -- there's no t..."
links.text: Something's missing -- there's no tape in the player.

links.title: You: "Press PLAY again."
links.text: Press PLAY again.

links.title: You: "Press PRINT."
links.text: Press PRINT.

links.title: Mainframe: "With a quiet determination the prin..."
links.text: With a quiet determination the printer starts printing, a piece of paper unfolding like a hand-held fan. A black criss-cross of letters covers its surface.

links.title: Mainframe: "It sounds like something cracks, be..."
links.text: It sounds like something cracks, before the piece of paper starts filling up with pure black ink.

links.title: Interfacing: "Something's broken. Machines aren't..."
links.text: Something's broken. Machines aren't supposed to behave like this.

links.title: Mainframe: "Nothing happens."
links.text: Nothing happens.

links.title: You: "Read the printout."
links.text: Read the printout.

links.title: Mainframe: "It's a project report written by th..."
links.text: It's a project report written by the lead producer Andrew 'Andy' Schott about 'Wirrl Untethered', a radio game developed by studio Fortress Accident.

links.title: Mainframe: "The first few pages give an overvie..."
links.text: The first few pages give an overview of the capital and workforce, while the rest of it seems to be a production schedule.

links.title: You: "Read about capital... I want to kno..."
links.text: Read about capital... I want to know about *money*.

links.title: Mainframe: "In its short time of existence, For..."
links.text: In its short time of existence, Fortress Accident SCA managed to burn through truly *insane* amounts of money.

links.title: Mainframe: "The first tranche of seed financing..."
links.text: The first tranche of seed financing brought in 150,000 rel, but then came the *delays*.

links.title: Mainframe: "Eventually the damage reached 400,0..."
links.text: Eventually the damage reached 400,000 rel with only half of the game finished.

links.title: Electrochemistry: "Four-hundred thousand rel?! Jommai..."
links.text: Four-hundred thousand rel?! Jommaijoo, these guys knew how to party!

links.title: You: "Gosh, where did they get all this m..."
links.text: Gosh, where did they get all this money?

links.title: Mainframe: "Let's just say it was a *real adven..."
links.text: Let's just say it was a *real adventure* for their Igaunijan investor.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Igaunija -- a god-forsaken (and tin..."
links.text: Igaunija -- a god-forsaken (and tiny) territory in Graad that has not once, but twice wasted its independence on microfascism. The less said about Igaunija the better. Matter of fact, let's stop saying things about it right now and continue what we were doing.

links.title: You: "Read about the workforce... Who wor..."
links.text: Read about the workforce... Who worked there, how long?

links.title: Mainframe: "Fortress Accident employed 18 peopl..."
links.text: Fortress Accident employed 18 people, the bulk of the team composed of writers and concept artists. There were also radio programmers, sound engineers, a CEO, two marketing experts...

links.title: Mainframe: "...and a single overburdened produc..."
links.text: ...and a single overburdened producer who developed a habit of popping Pyrholidon in the basement to escape his obligations.

links.title: Electrochemistry: "But on the other hand, their obliga..."
links.text: But on the other hand, their obligations *were* piling up at an inhuman rate -- a rate that could only be amended by Pyrholidon.

links.title: Logic: "Why did Fortress Accident have so m..."
links.text: Why did Fortress Accident have so many concept artists?

links.title: You: "Wait, why did a *radio game* need s..."
links.text: Wait, why did a *radio game* need so many artists?

links.title: Mainframe: "It didn't."
links.text: It didn't.

links.title: You: "It didn't need so many concept arti..."
links.text: It didn't need so many concept artists?

links.title: Mainframe: "No, definitely not. A few more prod..."
links.text: No, definitely not. A few more producers could have come handy though -- especially when dealing with writers, some of whom routinely skipped work because of 'mental health issues' and extremely unprofessional sleep schedules...

links.title: Mainframe: "One of them even managed to steal s..."
links.text: One of them even managed to steal some valuable company property before skipping town for good.

links.title: You: "I don't really care. (Look at the t..."
links.text: I don't really care. (Look at the table of contents again.)

links.title: Mainframe: "The first few pages give an overvie..."
links.text: The first few pages give an overview of the capital and workforce, while the rest of it seems to be a production schedule.

links.title: You: "Skim through the production schedul..."
links.text: Skim through the production schedule, whatever it is.

links.title: Mainframe: "The production schedule depicts the..."
links.text: The production schedule depicts their glorious descent into bankruptcy.

links.title: You: "Because of the concept artists?"
links.text: Because of the concept artists?

links.title: Mainframe: "No, not the concept artists. It was..."
links.text: No, not the concept artists. It wasn't even the writers, with their panic attacks and three-hour lunches...

links.title: You: "Right, what happened?"
links.text: Right, what happened?

links.title: Mainframe: "It was impossible not to fail. The..."
links.text: It was impossible not to fail. The project was too large and no amount of money could satiate the ever-expanding ambitions of the development team.

links.title: Mainframe: "They tried to make a 4,000,000 rel..."
links.text: They tried to make a 4,000,000 rel game with 400,000 in their bank account.

links.title: Mainframe: "They thought they could bridge the..."
links.text: They thought they could bridge the gap with pure willpower and imagination.

links.title: Mainframe: "They couldn't."
links.text: They couldn't.

links.title: You: "I could have bridged the gap."
links.text: I could have bridged the gap.

links.title: Volition: "No, you couldn't have."
links.text: No, you couldn't have.

links.title: You: "What do you mean? I totally could h..."
links.text: What do you mean? I totally could have.

links.title: Conceptualization: "Definitely not."
links.text: Definitely not.

links.title: Volition: "Not a chance."
links.text: Not a chance.

links.title: Mainframe: "Even then, success remained within..."
links.text: Even then, success remained within an ever-narrowing margin of possibility that, despite everything, never entirely disappeared...

links.title: You: "Oh, so they were done in by their o..."
links.text: Oh, so they were done in by their own ambition.

links.title: Mainframe: "No. Even then success remained with..."
links.text: No. Even then success remained within an ever-narrowing margin of possibility that, despite everything, never entirely disappeared...

links.title: Mainframe: "That is, until they discovered the..."
links.text: That is, until they discovered the Valley of the Heads.

links.title: You: "The what?"
links.text: The what?

links.title: Mainframe: "At the eleventh hour, the lead desi..."
links.text: At the eleventh hour, the lead designer, Zsiemsk-born Sulisaw Zawisza, decided that what 'Wirrl Untethered' needed was a secret mystical location at the extreme edge of the map...

links.title: Mainframe: "This place was to be the *Valley of..."
links.text: This place was to be the *Valley of the Heads* -- where the heads of all the *headless* constructs could be found. The player would have been able to choose a head for their headless party member, and each head would been voiced on-air by a professional actor.

links.title: You: "This is some insane shit. Who were..."
links.text: This is some insane shit. Who were these people?

links.title: Mainframe: "The world had never seen their kind..."
links.text: The world had never seen their kind before and might never again.

links.title: You: "How many heads were there?"
links.text: How many heads were there?

links.title: Mainframe: "So many. At last count there were a..."
links.text: So many. At last count there were approximately 10,000 heads for 10,000 headless men, all of which could be endlessly recombined.

links.title: You: "How many combinations could you mak..."
links.text: How many combinations could you make out of that?

links.title: Mainframe: "Do you really want to know? There s..."
links.text: Do you really want to know? There seems to be a calculation here, but it may take a while...

links.title: You: "Yeah, how bad could it be?"
links.text: Yeah, how bad could it be?

links.title: You: "Keep going."
links.text: Keep going.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant taps his foot impati..."
links.text: The lieutenant taps his foot impatiently, his arms folded tight against his chest.

links.title: Electrochemistry: "He's dying for a cigarette. Come to..."
links.text: He's dying for a cigarette. Come to think of it, you are, too.

links.title: You: "Keep going."
links.text: Keep going.

links.title: Interfacing: "What if you broke the radiocomputer..."
links.text: What if you broke the radiocomputer? What if it's never going to stop?!

links.title: You: "Just let the numbers wash over you."
links.text: Just let the numbers wash over you.

links.title: You: "Okay, so that's what did them in?"
links.text: Okay, so that's what did them in?

links.title: You: "Please stop."
links.text: Please stop.

links.title: You: "What have I done?"
links.text: What have I done?

links.title: You: "Uh oh."
links.text: Uh oh.

links.title: You: "No, let's not go there."
links.text: No, let's not go there.

links.title: Mainframe: "Good call. It's more than the numbe..."
links.text: Good call. It's more than the number of atoms in the observable universe.

links.title: You: "That's pretty bad. So that's what d..."
links.text: That's pretty bad. So that's what did them in?

links.title: Mainframe: "Well, yeah. That, and the catastrop..."
links.text: Well, yeah. That, and the catastrophic data loss.

links.title: You: "The what now?"
links.text: The what now?

links.title: Mainframe: "On the nature of the data loss, the..."
links.text: On the nature of the data loss, there's ominously little information in the production log. It comes at the very end, where things get fuzzy and dark, where tables and numbers seem to vanish into an eerie nothingness, before their Igaunijan investor pulled the plug...

links.title: Mainframe: "What is clear is that one day an un..."
links.text: What is clear is that one day an unidentified numeric anomaly occurred on the East-Insulindian Lintel front, just as the 'Wirrl Untethered' project was being compiled that day.

links.title: You: "And the anomaly caused all the data..."
links.text: And the anomaly caused all the data to get lost in the air?

links.title: Mainframe: "When the project was returned, it w..."
links.text: When the project was returned, it was completely blank.

links.title: Mainframe: "The team spent weeks on the phone w..."
links.text: The team spent weeks on the phone with Lintel, the service provider, but despite their diagnostics they could never produce a satisfactory explanation or pay for the loss.

links.title: You: "What! They lost the whole game and..."
links.text: What! They lost the whole game and wouldn't even pay for it?

links.title: Mainframe: "Always read the terms of service."
links.text: Always read the terms of service.

links.title: Logic: "And let's face it, they didn't have..."
links.text: And let's face it, they didn't have any money left for a legal action.

links.title: You: "Wasn't there a copy of the game, a..."
links.text: Wasn't there a copy of the game, a *backup*?

links.title: Mainframe: "Mysteriously enough, it seems that..."
links.text: Mysteriously enough, it seems that the off-site copy happened to be *on-site* when the catastrophic data loss occurred...

links.title: Mainframe: "It was the lead programmer's respon..."
links.text: It was the lead programmer's responsibility to oversee weekly maintenance of the off-site copy and, well, keep it off-site. An explanatory note from the lead programmer has been attached.

links.title: You: "What does it say?"
links.text: What does it say?

links.title: Mainframe: "S. Luukanen-Kilde, the lead program..."
links.text: S. Luukanen-Kilde, the lead programmer of Fortress Accident: "The off-site copy was on-site because there was no *off-site* anymore, not for me, not after eight months of crunch."

links.title: Mainframe: ""I didn't have a home anymore, so I..."
links.text: "I didn't have a home anymore, so I started keeping it in the basement, in the ice bear refrigerator (near where I went to sleep). It was perfectly safe there, the temperature conditions were *optimal*."

links.title: You: "It's not very convincing, is it?"
links.text: It's not very convincing, is it?

links.title: Mainframe: "Her former colleagues would agree w..."
links.text: Her former colleagues would agree with you.

links.title: Interfacing: "She's right, actually -- nothing wr..."
links.text: She's right, actually -- nothing wrong with keeping this type of filament memory in a fridge.

links.title: You: "Seems like a perfectly reasonable e..."
links.text: Seems like a perfectly reasonable explanation.

links.title: Mainframe: "That's not what her colleagues thou..."
links.text: That's not what her colleagues thought.

links.title: You: "Is there anything else from this le..."
links.text: Is there anything else from this lead programmer? (Proceed.)

links.title: Mainframe: "The production schedule ends with a..."
links.text: The production schedule ends with a few random notes that seem to be added sometime later.

links.title: You: "I didn't understand a word of that."
links.text: I didn't understand a word of that.

links.title: Mainframe: "Something spooky happened with the..."
links.text: Something spooky happened with the machines and the game was lost.

links.title: You: "This must be the anomaly Soona ment..."
links.text: This must be the anomaly Soona mentioned in the church log.

links.title: You: "That sounds bad."
links.text: That sounds bad.

links.title: Mainframe: "No, it was good. Too good."
links.text: No, it was good. Too good.

links.title: You: "Read the notes at the end."
links.text: Read the notes at the end.

links.title: Mainframe: "Four months later by an unknown aut..."
links.text: Four months later by an unknown author: "I am the only one left and it's gotten rather damp here. A few other businesses have gone under too. Slipstream switched to making skis and the hairdressers just left, cursing Martinaise. They're right, though, something's seriously wrong with this place. Martinaise, all of it."

links.title: Mainframe: ""Still haven't gotten an answer fro..."
links.text: "Still haven't gotten an answer from Lintel about what happened. All I could get were the physical coordinates of the error on the East-Insulindian front on that day. Since the computation happened on-air, I reckoned it had to coincide with an actually existing location..."

links.title: Mainframe: ""I have compared the coordinates to..."
links.text: "I have compared the coordinates to a map of Revachol West. Turns out it's only 800 metres from here. The address is Saint-Brune 1147. I am going there to look this thing in the eye..."

links.title: Reaction Speed: "Saint-Brune 1147? That's what the s..."
links.text: Saint-Brune 1147? That's what the street sign next to the church said...

links.title: You: "Tear off the printout and throw it..."
links.text: Tear off the printout and throw it away.

links.title: Mainframe: "Tiles on the cube are still smoulde..."
links.text: Tiles on the cube are still smouldering, casting the framework in a soft glow. Virescent PLAY and PRINT keys shine on the keyboard.

links.title: Mainframe: "The paper is soaked with ink, its m..."
links.text: The paper is soaked with ink, its monochrome darkness spanning from margin to margin... It's not possible to make out any information.

links.title: You: ""What happened? It's just covered i..."
links.text: "What happened? It's just covered in ink."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Odd." The lieutenant runs his hand..."
links.text: "Odd." The lieutenant runs his hand over the ink-soaked paper, staining his fingertips. "Something is obviously broken here."

links.title: You: "Examine the printout again."
links.text: Examine the printout again.

links.title: Perception: "A single speck of white shines out..."
links.text: A single speck of white shines out from the shade -- for some reason the printer decided to spare this one tiny dot of paper.

links.title: Inland Empire: "Marked by the devil itself!"
links.text: Marked by the devil itself!

links.title: Physical Instrument: "Looks like gibberish. Better get ru..."
links.text: Looks like gibberish. Better get running again.

links.title: Logic: "This must be the information Soona..."
links.text: This must be the information Soona is looking for -- she knows how to make sense of it.

links.title: Perception: "It's just black upon black, nothing..."
links.text: It's just black upon black, nothing to see here.

links.title: You: "Tear off the printout."
links.text: Tear off the printout.

links.title: Mainframe: "It's blank. The lower edge of the p..."
links.text: It's blank. The lower edge of the paper has been torn off.

links.title: You: "[Leave.]"
links.text: [Leave.]

dialogueTree.title: Mainframe: "The dusty radiocomputer sleeps on i..."
dialogueTree.text: The dusty radiocomputer sleeps on its wired frame, forgotten and unused. Its keyboard has a rectangular ON/OFF button; a piece of paper still hangs from the printer.

links.title: You: ""Do you think I should turn it on?""
links.text: "Do you think I should turn it on?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""It's your call." He looks over his..."
links.text: "It's your call." He looks over his shoulder, then back at the machine. "You're in charge of this expedition, officer."

links.title: Savoir Faire: "Of course you should turn it on --..."
links.text: Of course you should turn it on -- don't you want to know what's on the filament?!

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Maybe the body has *stopped* decom..."
links.text: "Maybe the body has *stopped* decomposing somehow..." He looks over his shoulder. "I don't know. You're in charge of this expedition, officer."

links.title: Half Light: "Is the lieutenant a little... scare..."
links.text: Is the lieutenant a little... scared? Just now when he looked around.

links.title: Reaction Speed: "You can always do it *after* the fr..."
links.text: You can always do it *after* the fridge.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""We have one of these down at the s..."
links.text: "We have one of these down at the station, but I never really learned how to use it."

links.title: You: "Turn on the machine."
links.text: Turn on the machine.

links.title: Mainframe: "The machine lights up like some pre..."
links.text: The machine lights up like some prehistoric animal stirring from its slumber, revealing virescent PLAY and PRINT keys on the keyboard. The hatch on the machine's central compartment is wide open.

links.title: You: "[Step away.]"
links.text: [Step away.]

dialogueTree.title: Mainframe: "A dusty radiocomputer sleeps on its..."
dialogueTree.text: A dusty radiocomputer sleeps on its wired frame, forgotten and unused. Its keyboard has a rectangular ON/OFF button; a piece of paper still hangs from the printer.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Another radiocomputer..." says the..."
links.text: "Another radiocomputer..." says the lieutenant, watching you circle around the machine. "Just sitting here without anyone in sight."

links.title: Reaction Speed: "What he means is that these things..."
links.text: What he means is that these things cost *money*. Why would anyone just leave it behind?

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""But we're looking for a fridge and..."
links.text: "But we're looking for a fridge and we're pressed on time -- so..."

links.title: Esprit de Corps: "On the other hand... it's not that..."
links.text: On the other hand... it's not that I'm *not* interested in abandoned radiocomputers.

links.title: Interfacing: "This is the Rehm Civic radiocompute..."
links.text: This is the Rehm Civic radiocomputer, model RC5120, equipped with a Feld mainframe and a Rehm-compatible printer.

dialogueTree.title: Mainframe: "This appears to be some kind of mac..."
dialogueTree.text: This appears to be some kind of machine with a cube-shaped heart and a wired framework. The keyboard has a rectangular ON/OFF button; a piece of paper still hangs from the printer.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""A radiocomputer..." says the lieut..."
links.text: "A radiocomputer..." says the lieutenant, watching you circle around the machine. "Just sitting here without anyone in sight." He sounds surprised and a bit cautious.
